title: Insulinoma Causing Hypoglycemic Episodes
setup_script: A 35-year-old woman experiences recurrent episodes of diaphoresis, tremor, and confusion relieved by eating. Fasting glucose is 40 mg/dL with inappropriately elevated insulin and C-peptide levels. Abdominal MRI reveals a 1 cm lesion in the pancreatic tail.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Recognize Whipple's triad of hypoglycemia: symptoms, low glucose, relief with glucose.
Order supervised fast with measurement of insulin, C-peptide, proinsulin, and sulfonylurea levels to confirm endogenous hyperinsulinism.
Discuss localization techniques (endoscopic ultrasound, MRI, CT, intraoperative palpation) to identify small insulinomas.
Explain differential diagnosis including insulinoma, nesidioblastosis, factitious hypoglycemia.
Obtain a multidisciplinary consult (endocrinology, radiology) and counsel patient on surgical resection as definitive therapy.
Decide on laparoscopic distal pancreatectomy versus enucleation depending on lesion location and proximity to pancreatic duct.
Prepare for surgery with preoperative glucose optimization and discuss risk of pancreatitis and pancreatic fistula.
Perform laparoscopic distal pancreatectomy preserving spleen when possible; confirm lesion with intraoperative ultrasound.
Monitor intraoperative and postoperative glucose; treat with dextrose as needed.
Send tumor for pathology to confirm neuroendocrine tumor and evaluate for malignancy (Ki-67 index).
Postoperative management: check amylase, drain output; manage pancreatic leak if present.
Plan follow-up for cure assessment, including fasting glucose and imaging; counsel patient on recurrence risk and symptoms.

critical_decision_points: Confirming diagnosis of insulinoma using fasting test and biochemical markers.
Localizing small tumors with imaging and endoscopic ultrasound.
Selecting appropriate surgical approach (enucleation vs distal pancreatectomy).
Managing perioperative glucose and preventing pancreatic fistula.
Counseling about recurrence and postoperative surveillance.
